Introduction

COHEE is a theme created for coffee shops, to see it in your browser simply open dist\index.html. If you bought this theme, changes are you want to modify it to fit your needs, the easiest and reccommended way to do it is by using grunt and working under the src\ directory.

COHEE was created using LESS and Grunt, the theme package provides everything you need to process the source files and get a fully working theme, this process is automated by Grunt, and the configuration file is included so by just running the grunt command, you’ll:

  • Compile all LESS files
  • Automatically add CSS prefix to properties that need it
  • Compress images under the src/img directory
  • Run a local web server to develop the theme on
  • Automatically refresh the browser every time you update a LESS or HTML file
  • Automatically set up any bower package you want to install

If you’ve never used grunt before, don’t panic! It’s really easy to get started, especially if the configuration is already there for you. If you are stuck, don’t hesitate to contact me.

Setting up Grunt

If you don’t have Node.js already, you’ll need to install it, don’t worry if you don’t know what it is, it’s simply a runtime environment for Grunt. The website has install instruction for major operating systems. If you want to install it using a package manager check out Joyent’s guide on installing Node.js via package manager, it covers OSX; Windows and major Linux distributions.

Once Node.js is installed, you can install grunt using Node’s package manager.

$ npm install -g grunt-cli

The dollar sign represents the terminal prompt, you are not supposed to type it, just in case you were wondering. That will install grunt globally in our system, now fire up a terminal and navigate to the theme’s src/ directory. If you use Windows you can just right shift + right-click in the src/ folder and select “Open command window here”.

$ cd /downloads/cohee-theme/src
$ npm install

That will install all of grunt dependencies, it will take a while though! So be patient. There’s one final thing we have to do now, install bower.

$ npm install -g bower
$ bower install

Bower is a package manager for the web, it’s used to install things like jQuery and FontAwesome.

You are done! You can fire up grunt by typing grunt in the terminal, the browser will open with a fresh theme installation.

Customization

Everything you want to update resides in the src/ directory, if you are running Grunt as explained above, your changes will be applied as soon as you save the file and the browser will refresh automatically, either you update HTML, LESS or images. Do not change anything in dist/, that folder will be regenerated every time you run Grunt.

The theme’s source code structure looks like this:

src/
  img/             # contains all the images used by the theme
  js/
    main.js        # base skeleton for Javascript
  less/
    variables.less # contains all global variables used, mostly just colors
    common.less    # styles which are applied to all pages, home, single, etc
    home.less      # styles only relevant for the home page
    single.less    # styles only relevant for the single page
  index.html       # theme's home page
  single.html      # theme's single item page

Changing anything in the theme is pretty straight forward, remember it’s just HTML and CSS afterall! A pretty important thing to note is that if you want to change any color, you should update it in the less\variables.less file if possible, so the changes are consistent though all the theme.

Distribution

The development build works fine, it contains valid HTML5 and CSS and it’s a good base if you want to create a WordPress theme or anything like that, but if you plan on simply hosting the static files there’s an extra step you should take, running grunt dist will minify all HTML, CSS and Javascript. Once the task is over the dist/ folder will contain the final version of the theme, optimized for release.
